4.27.23  11:09 pm   Do you prefer quantity or quality? (Not of anything in particular. Just use the first thing that came to your mind when you read this.)

      the first thing that comes to my mind, on that question, is to assess whether or not i am currently in the mood to answer the unanswerable. but actually, because you phrased it in a relatively long way, my first thought during the reading of the question and before i'd finished it, was, "incoming unanswerable, must continue reading to see if the parentheses changes the question, standby for assessing whether or not to answer the unanswerable" and then as soon as i was done reading the question my thought was "confirmed unanswerable question, proceed to assess current appropriateness of attempting to answer unanswerable." i hope that helps

4.27.23  11:21 am   you said in an earlier question that apples and oranges are the same while I completely disagree. would you care to elaborate

      there is currently an "apples and oranges" reference in common english, which has persisted for quite some time, and is still very active today, by which people always seem to mention "apples and oranges" whenever they are talking about any 2 objects which are "impossible to compare." it's "like apples and oranges", they say. It seems absurd to me, because apples and oranges are actually ideal for comparison. They are both fruit and have many similarities, and their differences are therefore quite obvious. They are just about the perfect thing to compare. So sometimes i am driven so mad by this constant sort of zombie-like widespread mindless obsession with "apples and oranges" being so "hard to compare" that sometimes i just blurt out that they are the same. I bet it's been a hundred years since anyone has ever actually checked, to see if they are

4.27.23  9:45 am   whats cotton candy made of (they tell me its sugar and i dont believe them)

      non-cotton, and non-candy. There is a loophole however, because it's only required that each individual ingredient be either non-cotton OR non-candy. So indeed there is some candy in there, included because it's not cotton. And there is some cotton, included on the basis that it's not candy. but statistics tells us that there's still a lot of stuff in there that's neither cotton nor candy

4.26.23  10:13 am   If two things go to infinity in opposite directions, will they eventually meet back up to form a cycle? Or is the very beginning the only moment that they ever make contact?

      if they are in an infinite universe, then they will continue forever. but in due time they will travel through situations identical to ones they've encountered before. in fact, this will happen infinite times. but not in a steadily repeating pattern. it will happen in every different pattern, infinite times, and in infinite different patterns

4.26.23  7:01 am   how does this question go from my brain to yours

4.26.23  6:01 am   there are different ways you add text to already shown subtitles:

- the first one, you show the whole text at the start of a sentence.
- the second one, you add words to the text and , if it's centered, it changes position on the screen
- the third one, you add the whole text but it's masked and then you add words to that mask

so, here's my question: how do you decide which method to choose? 

     the second method you mentioned, in my opinion, always feels terrible and i never do it (unless by mistake). and the third one you mentioned i didn't understand your description. but here's my basic theory for it. first, some terminology... "word pops" is when the words appear one at a time. "cumulative word pops" means each new word appears, with the previous words staying there. "replace word pops" is when the new word appears and the old word disappears, with only 1 word ever on screen at a time. "entire phrase pop" is when multiple words appear at the same time. Generally, in my opinion, when doing cumulative word pops, it's very uncomfortable for the staying words to move when the new word hits. this is why your second option doesn't work for me. However, often, i might want the final result to have a centered feel to it. in that case, i actually use left justify and use spaces to get the final result how i want. then i do the cumulative word pops to work toward that, so the words don't jump. "Replacing word pops" usually means the words are fairly big, maybe even full screen. Replacing-wordpops tends to be uncomfortable if it's a normal (fast) paced sentence. replacing wordpops is usually best for like a 3 word sentence where all 3 words are strong and emphasized. Otherwise, when deciding whether to do cumulative wordpops vs displaying the whole thing all at once, this is what i've noticed: alltogether works better when the sentence is an already-known quantity. a typical sentence. in other words, when i expect the viewer to already know the sentence. in other words, it's a sentence with no surprises. such as: "how are you doing?" or "i'll see you tomorrow" or "i never noticed that". It's basically a sentence that functions as one word. it's a package deal that everyone already knows. That's when it's usually best to make the whole sentence appear at the same time. But when the sentence is more unique, or has surprises in it, that's when you want cumulative word pops. Another method, for different situations, is "letter type" where it appears one letter at a time, steadily. This seems to be best when it seems to be some kind of pre-written, impersonal, formal message
